configuration.stem: Reorganized table, looks crummy on mobile tho -- TK

cells.label: As air temperatures increase, the water molecules in this ice absorb energy and begin to vibrate just enough to break free and start to flow past one another to form a liquid.
cells.imageAlt: In this activity, you will drag and drop labels to describe if the water in the image gains or loses energy. Images show a calm lake on a warm fay, a lake beginning to freeze, a runing stream, and drops of water melting off an icicle.

cells.label: As air temperatures decrease, the molecules in liquid water begin to move more slowly until they only vibrate in place. The molecules form the rigid structure of solid water, or ice.
cells.imageAlt: In this activity, you will drag and drop labels to describe if the water in the image gains or loses energy. Images show a calm lake on a warm fay, a lake beginning to freeze, a runing stream, and drops of water melting off an icicle.

cells.label: As air temperatures increase, liquid water molecules absorb thermal energy and vibrate enough that some will escape the liquidâ€™s surface into the air above as water vapor.
cells.imageAlt: In this activity, you will drag and drop labels to describe if the water in the image gains or loses energy. Images show a calm lake on a warm fay, a lake beginning to freeze, a runing stream, and drops of water melting off an icicle.

cells.label: As water vapor molecules rise, they eventually enter colder air. This causes the molecules to vibrate at a slower rate and change to liquid water droplets.
cells.imageAlt: In this photograph, white fluffy clouds form against a bright azure sky.
